arm_group.description: Use of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) to induce a muscle fatigue resistance in intense exercises
Use of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) placebo to induce a muscle fatigue resistance

brief_summary.textblock:
The study hypothesis is a improved muscle fatigue resistance induced by low-level laser
      therapy applied between sets of intense exercises.

clinical_study.brief_title: Use of Low-level Laser Therapy (808nm) to Muscle Fatigue Resistance

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  healthy males

          -  physically active

          -  aged between 18-28 years old

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  smoker

          -  under medicine

          -  lower limb lesions limiting the flexion-extension of the knee joint

intervention.description: Use of low-level laser therapy(LLLT)or placebo-LLLT applied on quadriceps femoris muscles between sets of isokinetic knee flexion-extension exercise

link.description: Research Ethics Committee of the Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte

facility.name: Federal Univesity of Rio Grande do Norte

clinical_study.official_title: Use of Low-level Laser Therapy (808nm) to Muscle Fatigue Resistance: a Randomized Double-blind Crossover Trial

overall_official.affiliation: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Norte
overall_official.last_name: Wouber Hérickson de Brito Vieira, PhD

oversight_info.authority: Brazil: National Committee of Ethics in Research

primary_outcome.description: Evaluation of maximum repetitions of knee flexion-extension in isokinetic dynamometer. Volunteers were assessed on Monday (pre evaluation - baseline), on Wednesday performed a session of exercises and on Friday were assessed again (final evaluation).

reference.citation: Felismino AS, Costa EC, Aoki MS, Ferraresi C, de Araújo Moura Lemos TM, de Brito Vieira WH. Effect of low-level laser therapy (808 nm) on markers of muscle damage: a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled trial. Lasers Med Sci. 2013 Sep 5. [Epub ahead of print]

Ferraresi C, Hamblin MR, Parizotto NA. Low-level laser (light) therapy (LLLT) on muscle tissue: performance, fatigue and repair benefited by the power of light. Photonics Lasers Med. 2012 Nov 1;1(4):267-286.

Vieira WH, Ferraresi C, Perez SE, Baldissera V, Parizotto NA. Effects of low-level laser therapy (808 nm) on isokinetic muscle performance of young women submitted to endurance training: a randomized controlled clinical trial. Lasers Med Sci. 2012 Mar;27(2):497-504. Epub 2011 Aug 26.

Ferraresi C, de Brito Oliveira T, de Oliveira Zafalon L, de Menezes Reiff RB, Baldissera V, de Andrade Perez SE, Matheucci Júnior E, Parizotto NA. Effects of low level laser therapy (808 nm) on physical strength training in humans. Lasers Med Sci. 2011 May;26(3):349-58. doi: 10.1007/s10103-010-0855-0. Epub 2010 Nov 18.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Evaluation of median frequency by surface electromyography of quadriceps femoris muscles during maximum repetitions of knee flexion-extension in isokinetic dynamometer. Volunteers were assessed on Monday (pre evaluation - baseline), on Wednesday performed a session of exercises and on Friday were assessed again (final evaluation).

collaborator.agency: Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Norte

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
